title: 8 multi-discipline cyclocross riders to watch this winter

8 multi-discipline cyclocross riders to watch this winter

The road cycling off-season may mean most viewing dries up and fans are reduced to admiring riders’ holiday snaps on social media instead, but never fear, cyclocross is here to save the day with some actual racing. 

One of the most exciting aspects of modern cycling is watching riders compete at the top of their game across multiple disciplines, meaning some of them hardly get a break in a season that already runs for most of a year. 

Triple threats like Mathieu van der Poel and Tom Pidcock challenge for titles across road, cyclocross, and mountain bike events, while Belgian machine Wout van Aert seems at home on every surface and on every parcours. On the women’s side, the GOAT Marianne Vos is a multi-time champ in road, cyclocross and even track as well and Pauline Ferrand-Prévot has World Championships in road, cyclocross, three mountain bike disciplines and gravel.

While the biggest stars are either coming off injuries or joining the CX season late to grab some much-needed off-season, the stage is set for a new generation of riders to fight for the top spots and replicate their success. 

With a few rounds of the UCI World Cup under their belt and a long way to go until the end of CX action, here are eight multi-discipline names to watch this winter.

1. Thibau Nys

21-year-old Thibau Nys is the one to watch in the early stages of the cyclocross season. Last year’s under-23 UCI World Champion, he’s jumped up to the elite levels for this season and is continuing to impress. He stormed to victory in the season opener at Waterloo, Wisconsin, currently sits fifth on the UCI World Cup leaderboard with ten races to go and is leading the X2O Trofee series. 

The son of Sven Nys, one of the most successful CX riders of all time, Thibau has also enjoyed success on the road in his first pro season in 2023. He rounded off the podium in the Tour of Norway this year behind young Ineos pair Ben Tulett and Magnus Sheffield. 

2. Cameron Mason

Cameron Mason has got off to a dream start this season, becoming the first-ever Brit to win a medal at the European Championships earlier this month, finishing second. At the start of the race he was back in tenth, but he clawed his way back into a chasing group and almost bridged the gap to Michael Vanthourenhout, who led all the way.

Mason finished just seven seconds down on the winner and in doing so the 23-year-old truly announced himself as an elite contender after a few years on the rise. He was also a major part of the six-man British contingent that claimed a silver medal in the CX team relay. 

While he sticks to the rough stuff, the Scot competes in several MTB disciplines and featured at the pointy end of some of the UCI World Series gravel races in 2023.

3. Puck Pieterse

Another one of the up-and-coming generation taking on the mantle of historic Dutch cyclocross success, 21-year-old Pieterse finished with a silver medal in the UCI World Cup series in 2022-23. She had an even better season on the mountain bike, coming first overall in the UCI’s Mountain Bike World Cup in both the XCO and XCC disciplines in her first season in the elites. 

In CX, she claimed the U23 European Championships title last season and has got off to a strong start this winter, coming second in the World Cup’s opening races in Waterloo and this weekend in Troyes. 

She’s also racing this season with the added boost of the National Champions’ jersey – not bad going considering the wealth of talent in the Dutch contingent – and she never finished lower than third last season, some talent.

Pieterse even took on two one-day road races in 2023 for Fenix-Deceuninck, one of which was her WorldTour debut, finishing an incredible fifth at Strade Bianche behind only Demi Vollering, Lotte Kopecky, Cecilie Uttrup Ludwig and Annemiek van Vleuten. Not bad company.

4. Shirin van Anrooij

Shirin van Anrooij was third on the women’s UCI World Cup podium last year, sharing each of the 14 wins with compatriots Pieterse and Fem van Empel. 

2023 was a great year for her on the road too, winning her first WorldTour race at Trofeo Alfredo Binda in March as well as winning the first women’s Tour de l’Avenir and the overall Women’s WorldTour young riders’ classification and finishing fifth overall at the Giro Donne. Although she’s already said she will limit her off-road racing this season to focus on next year’s Spring Classics, her early results so far make her one to watch. 

5. Zoe Bäckstedt

Zoe Bäckstedt has gone from strength to strength over the past couple of years and has already made her mark in this cyclocross season. She sits in third place after four races of the UCI World Cup, leading the under-23 classification, and also won the under-23s European Championships, adding another rainbow jersey to her collection. 

Still only 19, she dominates the under-23 field but is also already earning her stripes at elite level, although with the wealth of young talent even just on this list, getting her first elite win won’t be easy.

You probably already know she’s also a major name to watch elsewhere, having won world titles across three different disciplines – road (both road and time-trial), track, and cyclocross – at junior level.

6 and 7. Ava and Isabella Holmgren

Cycling is full of talented siblings, from Adam and Simon Yates to Zoe and Elynor Bäckstedt, and Canada’s Holmgren twins are the next exciting pair to watch. 

Ava came second in the overall World Cup under-19 standings last year, with her sister just behind in third and they’ve continued their impressive form so far this year: Isabella won the Women’s Elite Panamerican Continental Championships, while Ava took silver in the under-23 category. 

Aged just 18, both signed two-year contracts with Lidl-Trek this summer, so it’ll be exciting to see how their stellar junior careers develop at WorldTour level.

8. Cat Ferguson

Still just a junior, Cat Ferguson’s profile has steadily risen over the past couple of years and she’s one to watch in her last year before transitioning to senior racing. Fourth in last year’s junior European Championships, she took a stunning silver medal at this year’s in Pontchâteau, making the most of a strong starting position to lead the pack. 

She fought off a late charge from Viktória Chladonová to secure second step on the podium, but went one better in the under-19 World Cup round in Troyes a couple of weeks later – again one step ahead of Chladonová. 

Ferguson also races on the road, she won the junior Tour of Flanders and Trofeo Alfredo Binda in 2023 and came second in the World Championships junior road race and tenth in the TT (and third and first respectively in those races at nationals) and signed for Movistar earlier this year, she’ll join the team int he back half of 2024.

This list could have been endless with the amount of talent on display and we’re only a few weeks into the season. Who’s your one to watch for 2023/24?
